title: Epithelial cell spreading assay on E-cadherin-coated glass or PDMS substrates for microscopy-based analysis of cadherin adhesions
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of PDMS gels
Timing: 4–5 h
Traction force microscopy (TFM) using PDMS substrates can be used to infer patterns of mechanical stress thereby providing quantitative information on cellular mechanics.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4],5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5] E-cadherin coating of PDMS substrates allows for the detection of traction forces at AJ.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] In particular, it was used to visualize E-cadherin-dependent force transmission of F-actin retrograde flows.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] Before the E-cadherin coat can be applied, nano bead-embedded PDMS gels have to be generated.
Thoroughly mix equal quantities of CY-52-276 A and CY-52-276 B.
Note: This protocol generates PDMS gels with a stiffness of 10–20 kPa. Different stiffnesses can be obtained by changing the CY-52-276 A : CY-52-276 B ratio.
Pipette 120 μL of mix into the center of a single well from a 2-well Eppendorf chamber.
Spin-coat the solution using centrifugation for 1 min at 500 G to achieve an evenly spread flat gel.
You can use a Laurell WS-650MZ-23NPPB for spin-coating.
Cure gel for 2 h at 80°C.
Add 2 mL 5% 3-aminopropyl trimethoxysilane (APTES) in 100% EtOH to silanize gel.
Incubate gel for 5 min at 20°C–22°C in a flow hood.
Wash gel 3 times with 100% EtOH.
Dry gel for 15 min at 80°C.
Add 2 mL of 200 nm carboxylated fluorescent beads to gel.
To prepare the carboxylated fluorescent beads, dilute beads 1:2000 in dH2O.
Sonicate mixture for 10 min.
Pass mixture through a 0.45 μm filter to prevent clumping of the beads.
Incubate gel for 5 min at 20°C–22°C.
Wash gel 3 times with dH2O.
Dry gel for 15 min at 80°C.
Passivate gel with 2 mL 100 mM tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane (Tris) in dH2O for 5 min at 20°C–22°C.
Wash gel 3 times with dH2O.
Dry gel for 15 min at 80°C.
Gel is ready for E-cadherin coating.

Gel can be stored at 4°C in the dark for up to 4 weeks. Carefully wrap the Eppendorf chamber in parafilm, to prevent gel from drying out.
Coating with recombinant hE-cadherin/Fc
Timing: 2 days
E-cadherin-coated substrates can be generated on top of glass coverslips or PDMS gels. The steps below apply to both unless indicated otherwise. See Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] for schematic representation of E-cadherin-coated substrate.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3038-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. E-cadherin-coated substrate
Schematic representation of a MCF7 cell spread on E-cadherin ecto-domain ligands.
Prepare glass coverslips as indicated in “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” or PDMS gels as indicated above.
Add 1 mL 25 μg/mL Protein A in PBS to coverslips.
Critical: Make sure coverslips do not fall dry after addition of Protein A.
Incubate coverslips for 3 h at 20°C–22°C.
Wash coverslips 3 times with PBS.
Gently aspirate PBS and add new PBS at the same time, to prevent coverslips from falling dry.
Add 30 μL 25 μg/mL hE-cadherin/Fc in PBS to coverslips.
For PDMS gels add 200 μL.
Incubate coverslips 16–20 h at 4°C.
Wash coverslips 3 times with PBS.
Add 1 mL 1% BSA in PBS to coverslips.
Incubate coverslips for 45 min at 20°C–22°C.
Wash coverslips 3 times with PBS.
Add 1 mL movie media to coverslips.
E-cadherin-coated coverslips are ready for spreading assay.
It is recommended to directly use the E-cadherin-coated substrate in a spreading assay. If required, substrates can be stored in the dark for up to 1 week.
Epithelial cell spreading assay on E-cadherin-coated substrates
Timing: 3 h
Epithelial cells can be seeded on top of E-cadherin-coated glass coverslips or PDMS gels. The steps below apply to both. See Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2] for microscopy images of LifeAct-GFP expressing MCF7 cells seeded on top of E-cadherin-coated glass coverslips and PDMS gels.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3038-Fig2.jpg

Figure 2. Spreading on E-cadherin-coated glass and PDMS substrate
MCF7 cells expressing LifeAct-GFP (green) spread on E-cadherin ecto-domain-coated glass (left) or nano bead-embedded (orange) PDMS gel (right).
Prepare epithelial cells as indicated in “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” and E-cadherin-coated glass coverslips or PDMS gels as indicated above.
Wash cells in PBS.
Add 1X trypsin in PBS and incubate just long enough to see the first cells rounding up.
For MCF7 cells this is about 6 min, but this is cell-type dependent.
Resuspend cells in movie media.
Centrifuge for 3 min at 500 G to pellet cells.
Remove supernatant.
Resuspend cells in movie media.
Filter cells through 40 μm cell strainer to generate single cells.
Seed cells on top of prepared E-cadherin-coated substrates.
Closely monitor cells spreading.
Most MCF7 cells will be fully spread after 2 h, but this is cell-type dependent.
